required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Myocardial Infarction, COmbined-device, Recovery Enhancement Study
clinical_study.official_title: The Johns Hopkins Myocardial Infarction, COmbined-device, Recovery Enhancement (MiCORE) Study

brief_summary.textblock:
Unplanned readmissions after hospitalization for acute myocardial infarction (AMI) are among the leading causes of preventable morbidity, mortality, and healthcare costs. Digital health interventions (DHI) could be an effective tool in promoting self-management, adherence to guideline directed therapy, and cardiovascular risk reduction.
A DHI developed at Johns Hopkins-the Corrie Health Digital Platform-includes the first cardiology Apple CareKit smartphone application, paired with an Apple Watch and iHealth Bluetooth-enabled blood pressure monitor. Corrie targets: (1) self-management of cardiac medications, (2) self-tracking of vital signs, (3) education about cardiovascular disease through articles and animated videos, and (4) care coordination that includes cardiac rehabilitation and outpatient follow-up appointments.
In this prospective study, STEMI or type 1 NSTEMI patients are being enrolled to use the Corrie Health Digital Platform beginning early during participants' hospital stay. Enrollment sites include Johns Hopkins Hospital, Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center, Massachusetts General Hospital, and Reading Hospital. The primary objective is to compare time to first readmission within 30 days post-discharge among patients with the Corrie Health Digital Platform to patients in the historical standard of care comparison group.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Single group assignment to the Corrie Health Digital Platform prospective intervention group (n=200), as compared with a historical standard of care comparison group (n=864)

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Readmitted Within 30-days Post Hospital Discharge
primary_outcome.description: Number of participants readmitted within 30-days post hospital discharge in the Corrie Digital Health Group as compared to the Historical Standard of Care Comparison group, collected from hospital administrative databases.

secondary_outcome.measure: Cost-effectiveness as Assessed by a Markov Model of Cost-effectiveness
secondary_outcome.description: We estimated typical costs associated with readmissions or death of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) patients discharged with standard practices using 2014 US hospital costs from the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ). The hospital cost (in US dollars) for unplanned 30-day readmission is presented for the Corrie Digital Health Platform Group and the Historical Comparison Group. The reported number is the estimated cost per readmission per participant since the exact cost of the readmission for each patient who was readmitted within 30-days wasn't available. No measure of central tendency is available.

secondary_outcome.measure: In-hospital Care Satisfaction as Assessed by a Subset of the Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems Survey (9 Items)
secondary_outcome.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, a nine-item five-point Likert scale for assessing in-hospital care satisfaction 3 days post-discharge is used with scoring from 1 "strongly disagree" to 5 "strongly agree", with higher scores meaning participants were more satisfied with the care received. A total score of these nine items is calculated with possible total scores ranging from 9 to 45.

secondary_outcome.measure: In-hospital Care Satisfaction as Assessed by a Subset of the Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems Survey (Summary Score)
secondary_outcome.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, a nine-item five-point Likert scale for assessing in-hospital care satisfaction 3 days post-discharge is used with scoring from 1 "strongly disagree" to 5 "strongly agree", with higher scores meaning participants were more satisfied with the care received. A total score of these nine items is calculated with possible total scores ranging from 9 to 45.

secondary_outcome.measure: In-hospital Care Satisfaction as Assessed by a Subset of the Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems Survey (1 Dichotomous Item)
secondary_outcome.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, one additional item, not on the five-point Likert scale, for assessing in-hospital care satisfaction 3 days post-discharge asked if they received information in writing about what symptoms or health problems to look out for after leaving the hospital (Yes/No).

secondary_outcome.measure: In-hospital Care Satisfaction as Assessed by a Subset of the Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems Survey (1 Continuous Item)
secondary_outcome.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, one additional item, not on the five-point Likert scale, for assessing in-hospital care satisfaction 3 days post-discharge asked them to provide an overall hospital rating on a 1-10 sliding scale with a higher score indicating a higher overall hospital rating.

secondary_outcome.measure: Perceived Usability of Corrie as Assessed by the Systems Usability Scale
secondary_outcome.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, a 10-item five-point Likert scale for assessing systems usability of Corrie both 3 and 30 days post-discharge is used with scoring from 0 to 4 and higher scores meaning patients perceive the system as having global usability. The total score reference range is from 0 to 100, where lower scores indicate lower perceived application usability.

secondary_outcome.measure: Perceived Corrie App Satisfaction as Assessed by a Study Team Developed Scale
secondary_outcome.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, a five-item five-point Likert scale for assessing participant satisfaction with Corrie as a tool to improve acute myocardial infarction recovery 3 and 30 days post-discharge is used with scoring from 1 to 5 and higher scores meaning more satisfaction with Corrie. Total possible scores ranging from 5 to 25, where higher scores indicate greater Corrie app satisfaction.

secondary_outcome.measure: User Engagement With Corrie App as Assessed by the User Engagement Scale
secondary_outcome.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, a 29-item five-point Likert scale for assessing the subjective experience of user engagement with Corrie 30 days post discharge is used with scoring ranging from 1 to 5 and higher scores reflecting higher perceived user engagement. The total subjective user engagement score was calculated by diving the sum of all items by 29, resulting in a range of potential total scores from 1 to 5.

secondary_outcome.measure: User Engagement With Corrie Health App as Assessed by the Total Number of Interactions Per Participant in the Smartphone App, Collected Via Corrie Health Platform User Analytics
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout the study period for app usage up to 30 days post-discharge from the hospital
secondary_outcome.description: The total number of app interactions is a behavioral manifestation of user engagement and is monitored through app usage data. The total number of app interactions consisted of: number of BP, heart rate,weight, mood, and step count recordings; number of medications tracked; and number of educational articles and videos viewed over the study period.

secondary_outcome.measure: User Engagement With Corrie Health App as Assessed by the Overall Amount of Time Spent Using the App, Collected Via Corrie Health Platform App User Analytics
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout the study period for app usage up to 30 days post-discharge from the hospital
secondary_outcome.description: The overall amount of time (days) spent using the app is a behavioral manifestation of user engagement and is monitored through app usage data and collected via Corrie Health Platform app user analytics.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient Activation as Assessed by the Patient Activation Measure
secondary_outcome.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, the 10-item five-point Likert scale for assessing patient activation 3 and 30 days post-discharge is used with scoring ranging from 1 to 5 and higher scores indicating the patient possesses the necessary knowledge, skills, and confidence needed for self-care. The total score reference range is from 0 to 100, where lower scores indicate lower patient activation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Cardiac Medication Adherence as Assessed by the Adherence to Refills and Medications Scale Subscale
secondary_outcome.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, the eight-item four-point Likert scale for assessing cardiac medication adherence 30 days post-discharge is used with scoring ranging from 1 to 4 and lower scores indicating better adherence. Total possible scores could range from 8 to 32 with lower scores indicating better adherence. The total cardiac medication adherence score was dichotomized into completely cardiac medication adherent and near completely cardiac medication adherent, based on the median score.

secondary_outcome.measure: Cardiac Medication Adherence as Assessed by Smartphone App Usage Data
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout the study period for app usage up to 30 days post-discharge from the hospital
secondary_outcome.description: Cardiac medication adherence (beta-blockers, anti-platelets, statins) is measured from the smartphone app usage data as the percentage of cardiac medications marked as "taken".

secondary_outcome.measure: Medication Adherence as Assessed by Smartwatch App Usage Data
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout the study period for app usage up to 30 days post-discharge from the hospital
secondary_outcome.description: Medication adherence is measured from the smartwatch app usage data as percent of pills marked as taken.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Who Had Emergency Department Visits Within 30-days Post Hospital Discharge
secondary_outcome.description: Number of participants who had Emergency department visits (at Johns Hopkins Hospital and Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center) within 30-days post hospital discharge, that did not result in readmission, in the Corrie Digital Health Group as compared to the Historical Standard of Care Comparison group, collected from hospital administrative databases.

Number of hospital observations within 30-days post hospital discharge in the Corrie Digital Health Group as compared to the Historical Standard of Care Comparison group, collected from hospital administrative databases.

secondary_outcome.measure: Attendance of Follow-up Appointments as Assessed by Post-discharge Survey Developed by Study Team
secondary_outcome.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, the investigators are querying participants in the surveys sent out 30 days post-discharge as to whether participants attended an appointment with a primary care provider, cardiologist, and/or cardiac rehab. A point is given to each appointment attended with scores raging from 0 to 3.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Readmitted Participants Who Had Recurrent Myocardial Infarctions
secondary_outcome.description: Number of readmitted participants who had Recurrent myocardial infarctions in the Corrie Digital Health Group. Participants who had an all-cause 30-day readmission in the Corrie group, as identified by hospital administrative datasets, underwent further chart review to determine if the cause of readmission was a recurrent myocardial infarction.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Deaths Within 30 Days Post Hospital Discharge
secondary_outcome.description: Death within 30-days post hospital discharge in the Corrie Digital Health Group as compared to the Historical Standard of Care Comparison group, collected from hospital administrative databases.

arm_group.description: Receives the Corrie Health intervention plus the standard of care

intervention.description: The Corrie Health Digital Platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure monitor.

criteria.textblock:
Corrie Health Digital Platform group
Inclusion Criteria:
- Admitted for acute myocardial infarction (STEMI or Type 1 NSTEMI)
- 18 years or older
- English-speaking
- Own any type of smartphone
Exclusion Criteria:
- Visual, hearing, or motor impairment which precludes the use of the intervention
- Inability to participate due to severity of illness (e.g., intubated and on sedation in the setting of cardiogenic shock). If patients are deemed clinically unstable and unable to participate at the time of initial screening, the research team member returns at a later date to determine whether this status has changed.
Historical Standard of Care Comparison group
Inclusion Criteria:
- Admitted for acute myocardial infarction (STEMI or NSTEMI)
- 18 years or older
- English-speaking
Exclusion Criteria:
- None

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: 200 participants were enrolled in 4 hospitals to receive study intervention. 864 patients' data were pulled from hospital administrative data sets to be the historical comparison group.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Patients in the historical comparison group were not considered enrolled in this study.

group.title: Corrie Digital Health Platform Group
group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff.

group.description: Receives the standard of care

group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff.

group.title: Historical Comparison Group
group.description: Receives the standard of care

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: Age
Sex: Female, Male
Race/Ethnicity, Customized
Insurance status
measure.population: In historical comparison group a primary payer for insurance of "Workers compensation/unknown" considered as "unknown".

measure.title: Marital status
Body mass index
measure.population: 26.6% missing body mass index data for historical control group

measure.title: Smoking status
measure.population: 13.2% (114/864) of the participants in the historical comparison group had missing data for smoking status.

measure.title: Total Elixhauser comorbidity count
measure.population: Unweighted, Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality Elixhauser comorbidity count includes 29 comorbidities with no imputation for missing values. 2.5% missing data for the Corrie intervention group and 1.9% missing data for the historical comparison group.

measure.title: Hospital of Admission
Type of Acute Myocardial Infarction
Intervention (during index admission)

category.title: Coronary artery bypass grafting surgery alone

measure.title: Length of stay
Discharge disposition
Duration of education
measure.population: 31% missing data for formal education in the Corrie group. This data is not available in the electronic medical record so it could not be obtained for the historical comparison group.

measure.title: Household income per year
measure.population: 54.5% missing data on household income for the Corrie intervention group. This data is not available in the electronic medical record so it could not be obtained for the historical comparison group.

outcome.title: Number of Participants Readmitted Within 30-days Post Hospital Discharge
outcome.description: Number of participants readmitted within 30-days post hospital discharge in the Corrie Digital Health Group as compared to the Historical Standard of Care Comparison group, collected from hospital administrative databases.

group.title: Corrie Digital Health Platform Group
group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff.

group.title: Historical Comparison Group
group.description: Receives the standard of care

measure.title: Number of Participants Readmitted Within 30-days Post Hospital Discharge
measure.description: Number of participants readmitted within 30-days post hospital discharge in the Corrie Digital Health Group as compared to the Historical Standard of Care Comparison group, collected from hospital administrative databases.

analysis.p_value_desc: The a priori threshold for statistical significance was <0.05.
analysis.method_desc: Adjusting for hospital site and a propensity score inclusive of individual level baseline characteristics.

outcome.title: Cost-effectiveness as Assessed by a Markov Model of Cost-effectiveness
outcome.description: We estimated typical costs associated with readmissions or death of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) patients discharged with standard practices using 2014 US hospital costs from the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ). The hospital cost (in US dollars) for unplanned 30-day readmission is presented for the Corrie Digital Health Platform Group and the Historical Comparison Group. The reported number is the estimated cost per readmission per participant since the exact cost of the readmission for each patient who was readmitted within 30-days wasn't available. No measure of central tendency is available.
outcome.population: 200 patients enrolled in the Corrie group as compared to data from the historical comparison group as well as model estimates obtained from the literature for the standard of care comparison. Model estimates from the literature were used to supplement information when data was not available from the historical comparison group. The addition of the model estimates from the literature ensured the testing of representative, real-world values.

group.title: Corrie Digital Health Platform Group
group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff. obtained from the literature.

group.title: Historical Comparison Group
group.description: Receives the standard of care

measure.title: Cost-effectiveness as Assessed by a Markov Model of Cost-effectiveness
measure.description: We estimated typical costs associated with readmissions or death of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) patients discharged with standard practices using 2014 US hospital costs from the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ). The hospital cost (in US dollars) for unplanned 30-day readmission is presented for the Corrie Digital Health Platform Group and the Historical Comparison Group. The reported number is the estimated cost per readmission per participant since the exact cost of the readmission for each patient who was readmitted within 30-days wasn't available. No measure of central tendency is available.
measure.population: 200 patients enrolled in the Corrie group as compared to data from the historical comparison group as well as model estimates obtained from the literature for the standard of care comparison. Model estimates from the literature were used to supplement information when data was not available from the historical comparison group. The addition of the model estimates from the literature ensured the testing of representative, real-world values.

analysis.non_inferiority_desc: A Markov Model of cost-effectiveness, based on 30-day readmission rates, was built to assess the Incremental Cost-Effectiveness Ratio (ICER) of adopting the Corrie Platform compared to standard of care for post AMI patients; taking into account the estimated cost of Corrie ($2,750 per patient for a 1-year use term). The reported value is a ratio of the relative cost of intervention compared to the standard of care divided by the change in the outcome, quality-adjusted life years (QALYs).
analysis.estimate_desc: A negative ICER means the intervention cost is lower than the cost of standard of care, while the denominator was positive. A positive ICER means the intervention cost is greater than the cost of standard of care, while the denominator was positive.

outcome.title: In-hospital Care Satisfaction as Assessed by a Subset of the Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems Survey (9 Items)
outcome.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, a nine-item five-point Likert scale for assessing in-hospital care satisfaction 3 days post-discharge is used with scoring from 1 "strongly disagree" to 5 "strongly agree", with higher scores meaning participants were more satisfied with the care received. A total score of these nine items is calculated with possible total scores ranging from 9 to 45.
outcome.population: 89 participants completed all the items on the survey, except for one where one person did not fill out the item/question, resulting in 88 being analyzed for that item.

group.title: Corrie Digital Health Platform Group
group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff.

measure.title: In-hospital Care Satisfaction as Assessed by a Subset of the Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems Survey (9 Items)
measure.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, a nine-item five-point Likert scale for assessing in-hospital care satisfaction 3 days post-discharge is used with scoring from 1 "strongly disagree" to 5 "strongly agree", with higher scores meaning participants were more satisfied with the care received. A total score of these nine items is calculated with possible total scores ranging from 9 to 45.
measure.population: 89 participants completed all the items on the survey, except for one where one person did not fill out the item/question, resulting in 88 being analyzed for that item.

class.title: I would recommend this hospital to my friends and family.
During this hospital stay, the nurses treated me with courtesy and respect.
During this hospital stay, the nurses listened carefully to me.
During this hospital stay, the nurses explained things in a way I could understand.
During this hospital stay, the doctors treated me with courtesy and respect.
During this hospital stay, the doctors listened carefully to me.
During this hospital stay, the doctors explained things in a way I could understand.
The hospital staff talked with me about whether I would have the help I needed after leaving.
Before giving any new medications, hospital staff described clearly potential side effects.

measure.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, a 29-item five-point Likert scale for assessing the subjective experience of user engagement with Corrie 30 days post discharge is used with scoring ranging from 1 to 5 and higher scores reflecting higher perceived user engagement. The total subjective user engagement score was calculated by diving the sum of all items by 29, resulting in a range of potential total scores from 1 to 5.
measure.population: 102 participants completed the survey at 30 days post-discharge

outcome.title: User Engagement With Corrie Health App as Assessed by the Total Number of Interactions Per Participant in the Smartphone App, Collected Via Corrie Health Platform User Analytics
outcome.description: The total number of app interactions is a behavioral manifestation of user engagement and is monitored through app usage data. The total number of app interactions consisted of: number of BP, heart rate,weight, mood, and step count recordings; number of medications tracked; and number of educational articles and videos viewed over the study period.
outcome.time_frame: Throughout the study period for app usage up to 30 days post-discharge from the hospital
outcome.population: Following deployment of Corrie backend capabilities (the Corrie backend was not set up to capture application interactions for the first 34 participants enrolled), 83% (138/166) of Corrie users had captured application interactions (i.e. used the Corrie platform at least once over the 30-day study and subsequently connected to WiFi or cellular data to connect with the backend).

group.title: Corrie Digital Health Platform Group
group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff.

measure.title: User Engagement With Corrie Health App as Assessed by the Total Number of Interactions Per Participant in the Smartphone App, Collected Via Corrie Health Platform User Analytics
measure.description: The total number of app interactions is a behavioral manifestation of user engagement and is monitored through app usage data. The total number of app interactions consisted of: number of BP, heart rate,weight, mood, and step count recordings; number of medications tracked; and number of educational articles and videos viewed over the study period.
measure.population: Following deployment of Corrie backend capabilities (the Corrie backend was not set up to capture application interactions for the first 34 participants enrolled), 83% (138/166) of Corrie users had captured application interactions (i.e. used the Corrie platform at least once over the 30-day study and subsequently connected to WiFi or cellular data to connect with the backend).

outcome.title: User Engagement With Corrie Health App as Assessed by the Overall Amount of Time Spent Using the App, Collected Via Corrie Health Platform App User Analytics
outcome.description: The overall amount of time (days) spent using the app is a behavioral manifestation of user engagement and is monitored through app usage data and collected via Corrie Health Platform app user analytics.
outcome.time_frame: Throughout the study period for app usage up to 30 days post-discharge from the hospital
outcome.population: Following deployment of Corrie backend capabilities (the Corrie backend was not set up to capture application interactions for the first 34 participants enrolled), 83% (138/166) of Corrie users had captured application interactions (i.e. used the Corrie platform at least once over the 30-day study and subsequently connected to WiFi or cellular data to connect with the backend).

group.title: Corrie Digital Health Platform Group
group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff.

measure.title: User Engagement With Corrie Health App as Assessed by the Overall Amount of Time Spent Using the App, Collected Via Corrie Health Platform App User Analytics
measure.description: The overall amount of time (days) spent using the app is a behavioral manifestation of user engagement and is monitored through app usage data and collected via Corrie Health Platform app user analytics.
measure.population: Following deployment of Corrie backend capabilities (the Corrie backend was not set up to capture application interactions for the first 34 participants enrolled), 83% (138/166) of Corrie users had captured application interactions (i.e. used the Corrie platform at least once over the 30-day study and subsequently connected to WiFi or cellular data to connect with the backend).

outcome.title: Patient Activation as Assessed by the Patient Activation Measure
outcome.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, the 10-item five-point Likert scale for assessing patient activation 3 and 30 days post-discharge is used with scoring ranging from 1 to 5 and higher scores indicating the patient possesses the necessary knowledge, skills, and confidence needed for self-care. The total score reference range is from 0 to 100, where lower scores indicate lower patient activation.
outcome.population: At 3-days post discharge only 94 participants completed the survey while at 30 days post-discharge 103 participants completed the survey.

group.title: Corrie Digital Health Platform Group
group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff.

measure.title: Patient Activation as Assessed by the Patient Activation Measure
measure.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, the 10-item five-point Likert scale for assessing patient activation 3 and 30 days post-discharge is used with scoring ranging from 1 to 5 and higher scores indicating the patient possesses the necessary knowledge, skills, and confidence needed for self-care. The total score reference range is from 0 to 100, where lower scores indicate lower patient activation.
measure.population: At 3-days post discharge only 94 participants completed the survey while at 30 days post-discharge 103 participants completed the survey.

outcome.title: Cardiac Medication Adherence as Assessed by the Adherence to Refills and Medications Scale Subscale
outcome.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, the eight-item four-point Likert scale for assessing cardiac medication adherence 30 days post-discharge is used with scoring ranging from 1 to 4 and lower scores indicating better adherence. Total possible scores could range from 8 to 32 with lower scores indicating better adherence. The total cardiac medication adherence score was dichotomized into completely cardiac medication adherent and near completely cardiac medication adherent, based on the median score.
outcome.population: 102 participants completed the survey at 30 days post-discharge.

group.title: Corrie Digital Health Platform Group
group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff.

measure.title: Cardiac Medication Adherence as Assessed by the Adherence to Refills and Medications Scale Subscale
measure.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, the eight-item four-point Likert scale for assessing cardiac medication adherence 30 days post-discharge is used with scoring ranging from 1 to 4 and lower scores indicating better adherence. Total possible scores could range from 8 to 32 with lower scores indicating better adherence. The total cardiac medication adherence score was dichotomized into completely cardiac medication adherent and near completely cardiac medication adherent, based on the median score.
measure.population: 102 participants completed the survey at 30 days post-discharge.

outcome.title: Cardiac Medication Adherence as Assessed by Smartphone App Usage Data
outcome.description: Cardiac medication adherence (beta-blockers, anti-platelets, statins) is measured from the smartphone app usage data as the percentage of cardiac medications marked as "taken".
outcome.time_frame: Throughout the study period for app usage up to 30 days post-discharge from the hospital
outcome.population: 135 patients who had app interaction data specific to cardiovascular disease (CVD) medications (beta-blocker, anti-platelet, statin) from admission through 30 days post-discharge.

group.title: Corrie Digital Health Platform Group
group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff.

measure.title: Cardiac Medication Adherence as Assessed by Smartphone App Usage Data
measure.description: Cardiac medication adherence (beta-blockers, anti-platelets, statins) is measured from the smartphone app usage data as the percentage of cardiac medications marked as "taken".
measure.population: 135 patients who had app interaction data specific to cardiovascular disease (CVD) medications (beta-blocker, anti-platelet, statin) from admission through 30 days post-discharge.
measure.units: percentage of any CVD meds marked taken

outcome.title: Medication Adherence as Assessed by Smartwatch App Usage Data
outcome.description: Medication adherence is measured from the smartwatch app usage data as percent of pills marked as taken.
outcome.time_frame: Throughout the study period for app usage up to 30 days post-discharge from the hospital
outcome.population: Unable to differentiate smartwatch app usage data from smartphone app usage data. Thus, results assessing medication adherence by smartwatch app is provided under as "assessed by smartphone app usage data" (Outcome 13).

group.title: Corrie Digital Health Platform Group
group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff.

measure.title: Medication Adherence as Assessed by Smartwatch App Usage Data
measure.description: Medication adherence is measured from the smartwatch app usage data as percent of pills marked as taken.
measure.population: Unable to differentiate smartwatch app usage data from smartphone app usage data. Thus, results assessing medication adherence by smartwatch app is provided under as "assessed by smartphone app usage data" (Outcome 13).

outcome.title: Number of Participants Who Had Emergency Department Visits Within 30-days Post Hospital Discharge
outcome.description: Number of participants who had Emergency department visits (at Johns Hopkins Hospital and Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center) within 30-days post hospital discharge, that did not result in readmission, in the Corrie Digital Health Group as compared to the Historical Standard of Care Comparison group, collected from hospital administrative databases.
outcome.population: 908 patients were enrolled at Johns Hopkins Hospital and Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center across both the Corrie intervention group (n=174) and historical comparison group (n=734). 80 of the patients had an emergency department visit within 30-days of discharge that resulted in a readmission and were excluded from this analysis. Hence, a total of 828 participants were included in the analysis across the Corrie intervention group (n=164) and the historical comparison group (n=664).

group.title: Corrie Digital Health Platform Group
group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff.

group.title: Historical Comparison Group
group.description: Receives the standard of care

measure.title: Number of Participants Who Had Emergency Department Visits Within 30-days Post Hospital Discharge
measure.description: Number of participants who had Emergency department visits (at Johns Hopkins Hospital and Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center) within 30-days post hospital discharge, that did not result in readmission, in the Corrie Digital Health Group as compared to the Historical Standard of Care Comparison group, collected from hospital administrative databases.
measure.population: 908 patients were enrolled at Johns Hopkins Hospital and Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center across both the Corrie intervention group (n=174) and historical comparison group (n=734). 80 of the patients had an emergency department visit within 30-days of discharge that resulted in a readmission and were excluded from this analysis. Hence, a total of 828 participants were included in the analysis across the Corrie intervention group (n=164) and the historical comparison group (n=664).

analysis.p_value_desc: The a priori threshold for statistical significance was <0.05.
analysis.method_desc: Adjusting for hospital site and a propensity score inclusive of individual level baseline characteristics.

outcome.title: Number of Hospital Observations
outcome.description: Number of hospital observations within 30-days post hospital discharge in the Corrie Digital Health Group as compared to the Historical Standard of Care Comparison group, collected from hospital administrative databases.
outcome.population: Unable to obtain this data from hospital administrative data sets. Data was not collected.

group.title: Corrie Digital Health Platform Group
group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff.

group.title: Historical Comparison Group
group.description: Receives the standard of care

measure.title: Number of Hospital Observations
measure.description: Number of hospital observations within 30-days post hospital discharge in the Corrie Digital Health Group as compared to the Historical Standard of Care Comparison group, collected from hospital administrative databases.
measure.population: Unable to obtain this data from hospital administrative data sets. Data was not collected.

outcome.title: Attendance of Follow-up Appointments as Assessed by Post-discharge Survey Developed by Study Team
outcome.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, the investigators are querying participants in the surveys sent out 30 days post-discharge as to whether participants attended an appointment with a primary care provider, cardiologist, and/or cardiac rehab. A point is given to each appointment attended with scores raging from 0 to 3.
outcome.population: 104 participants completed this survey question at 30 days post-discharge.

group.title: Corrie Digital Health Platform Group
group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff.

measure.title: Attendance of Follow-up Appointments as Assessed by Post-discharge Survey Developed by Study Team
measure.description: Among participants in the Corrie Digital Health group, the investigators are querying participants in the surveys sent out 30 days post-discharge as to whether participants attended an appointment with a primary care provider, cardiologist, and/or cardiac rehab. A point is given to each appointment attended with scores raging from 0 to 3.
measure.population: 104 participants completed this survey question at 30 days post-discharge.

outcome.title: Number of Readmitted Participants Who Had Recurrent Myocardial Infarctions
outcome.description: Number of readmitted participants who had Recurrent myocardial infarctions in the Corrie Digital Health Group. Participants who had an all-cause 30-day readmission in the Corrie group, as identified by hospital administrative datasets, underwent further chart review to determine if the cause of readmission was a recurrent myocardial infarction.
outcome.population: Total of 13 participants in the Corrie group who were readmitted within 30 days of discharge. Unable to obtain reason for readmission from the hospital administrative data sets. Thus, data on whether 30-day readmissions were due to recurrent myocardial infarction were not available for the historical comparison group. Chart review, to obtain this reason for readmission as done with the Corrie group, was not possible for the historical comparison group.

group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff.

Thus, data on whether 30-day readmissions were due to recurrent myocardial infarction were not available for the historical comparison group. Chart review, to obtain this reason for readmission as done with the Corrie group, was not possible for the historical comparison group.

outcome.description: Death within 30-days post hospital discharge in the Corrie Digital Health Group as compared to the Historical Standard of Care Comparison group, collected from hospital administrative databases.
outcome.population: Unable to obtain data from hospital administrative data sets. Data was not collected.

measure.title: Number of Deaths Within 30 Days Post Hospital Discharge
measure.description: Death within 30-days post hospital discharge in the Corrie Digital Health Group as compared to the Historical Standard of Care Comparison group, collected from hospital administrative databases.
measure.population: Unable to obtain data from hospital administrative data sets. Data was not collected.

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse event data were collected from the time of enrollment in the hospital to 30 days post-discharge, for the Corrie Digital Health Platform group.
reported_events.desc: While 30-day hospital readmission data was collected for both the Corrie Digital Health Platform and Historical Comparison groups this data is not listed here for the Historical Comparison group because they were not enrolled participants. All-cause mortality data could not be obtained from hospital administrative databases. It was reported to the study team by the participant's family member. This explains why outcome measure 20 has no data but 1 mortality reported here.

group.title: Corrie Digital Health Platform Group
group.description: Receives the Corrie Digital Health intervention plus the standard of care Corrie Digital Health platform: The Corrie Digital Health platform consists of the Corrie smartphone app for heart attack recovery which is paired with an Apple Watch and Bluetooth-enabled, iHealth blood pressure cuff. The sample size for reporting of adverse events is 216. 200 Corrie patients that finished the study plus 16 who were consented but later withdrew or were withdrawn from the study.

event.sub_title: Inpatient hospital readmission within 30 days post-discharge
event.description: Number of participants that were readmitted within 30 days post-discharge among the 200 Corrie participants that completed the study.

Report of bruising on participant forearm, where the Apple Watch was located. Bruising was reported in other locations. The participant was on blood thinners, with a history of bruising. It is uncertain if the Apple Watch contributed to bruising.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

point_of_contact.organization: Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine
